title: The MASH Project
segmentation: So hello, my name is Lenny.
This I.
Work for the depreciation student Switzerland and I'm here today to present the mass project.
Match is an EU project which is led by India and also involves researchers at Indian Centers Institutes in France.
Researchers at the University of Potsdam in, Germany.
Anas and also researchers at the Czech Tickling University in Prague.
The overall goal of the project is to develop tools that will allow communities to develop and exploit very large families of feature extractors and to do so in a principled manner.
So in recent years there seems to be a trend both in the machine learning communities and the vision communities.
To try to develop methods that are that are capable of exploiting information that have been obtained from multiple sources.
So for example, even here at DCML we saw a number of very interesting papers on Multiview learning.
And in computer vision, many of the state of the art systems now use features from multiple descriptors.
Like for example Geller and nobody's work.
For those who are familiar.
But there seems to be a drawback.
The fact that most of these systems usually depend only on a limited amount of.
Feature extractors and this is this is doing no in no small part to the fact that research group usually have to develop and fine tune these descriptors on their own.
So it's.
It's not.
It's quite typical that each each research group would have their own implementation of hogs, for example.
And what?

Machines to do is try to alleviate these obstacles by creating a collaborative framework, a framework that would allow users to develop these feature extractors in collaboration with with each others.
So in our framework, which is based around the web platform, the users would simply contribute feature extractors.
Which would be done by implementing a simple C++ class.
And the projects construction within contribute machine learning tools such as classifiers or predictors or goal planners.
And we're also sorry.
Then the construction would also contribute to different datasets and applications on which the users could evaluate their feature extractors.
So to be more specific.
User that would register to the site with the simply upload their C source code of their feature extractor, in which case we would the platform would save this.
Save this code in the in the user's private space.
So the code would be accessible only by the user and no one else.

Not even consortium has access to this to this code and the and the user would then be free to use the machine learning tools we've that are at his disposal to run experiments that will allow him to evaluate his feature extractor.
So to give an example we have, we have multiple applications we already targeting like image classification, object detection and goal planning.
So in the case of image classification, contributors simply upload a feature extractor which you could then combine with a with a classifier that we implement, like SVM or Adaboost or night bias.
In which we we allow the computer use and then you can choose from number of image classification datasets and evaluate his.
His feature extractor the nice thing for the user is that any experiments that you may schedule would be then be run on our servers.
So on the project servers.
Localeze, so the user himself would not have to dedicate any computational resources whatsoever, so he does not need the memory or the.
The CPU to run the experiments.
So once an experiment that is scheduled, the platform will then run the experiment on our service and.
Return feedback to the user in the form of, so we would the user would get different statistics on the performance of his feature extractor.
Like simple simple, dislike the test there, or more confusion metrics or even examples of misclassified samples.
And finally, the user also has the opportunity to make his code public at some point whenever whenever he pleases.
An at this case, at one, once the code is made public, it would be moved far away from his private space into repository, which is publicly available at the website under the GPL 2 license.
So the source code of these features access to the public feature extractors is then available to anyone who visits our website.
So we already have a long list of feature extractors that are publicly available to any blazer and can be downloaded.
I'm.
Let me just finish by saying that the web platform is situated at Mash Dash Project Dot U where we have an SDK.
That helps that helps users develop their feature extractors and we also have tutorials and screencasts that better explain or explain in more depth the framework and the web platform.
Thank you.
